recordings.loc: Bath, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
The sound of feral pigeons cooing and crashing around under the skew railway bridge next to Bath Spa station. The city is in lockdown due to Coronavirus/COVID-19 with no buses, no trains and very few people outside. It would not normally be easy to make a reasonable recording here due to the other sounds at the same frequency as the pigeons. The acoustics of the underside of a steel and stone bridge such as this mean that the sounds echo around, producing an overall very muddy sound to the birds but one which defines this odd soundscape. 

I made the recording in the cold with an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 microphone as a brief stop during permitted daily exercise. EQ mainly adjusted below 200 Hz to remove very light wind noise but also below 2000 Hz just to even up the scene.

Pedro the friendly feral pigeon waiting for their daily handful of seeds. 

Background sounds: plic-ploc sounds from a nearby water point

Distance: <50cm

Equipment: Olympus LS-12 (internal mics)
City park, high pass filter 200 Hz 48 dB, ZOOM H1n.

recordings.type: cooing, flapping wings, male, wing hits
recordings.rmk: Two male pigeons delimiting their nesting boundaries. First they were cooing opposite each other, then they hit each other with their wings (high-pitched noise) and started fighting with their beaks, trying to push the other out of the window sill (nails can be heard scratching the surface). At last one of them decided to stop arguing and both flew away (flapping wings are heard).
